I figure it's going to rain later, so I'll bring an umbrella.
It took me a few weeks to learn the lay of the land at my new job.
He is the king of the office, so to speak.

gram.name: so to speak
gram.function: 意为“可以说；打个比方说”，用于表示自己正在使用一种比喻或不太精确的说法。'...show you the lay of the land, so to speak' 意味着 'lay of the land' 是一个比喻，并非字面意思上的“地势”。

example.en: He is the king of the office, so to speak.
example.cn: 可以说，他是办公室里的老大。

gram.constraints: 用作插入语，通常放在句末，前面有逗号。

paras.en: Mr. Tushman was suddenly right in front of me, his hands on my shoulders. He leaned down and said very softly in my ear: "It'll be okay, August. These are nice kids, I promise." "You're going to be okay, Auggie," Mom whispered with all her might. Before she could say anything else, Mr. Tushman opened the door to his office. "Come on in, kids," he said, and in walked two boys and a girl. None of them looked over at me or Mom: they stood by the door looking straight at Mr. Tushman like their lives depended on it.
paras.cn: 塔什曼先生突然就在我面前，双手放在我的肩膀上。他俯下身，在我耳边非常轻柔地说：“会没事的，奥古斯特。这些都是好孩子，我保证。” “你会没事的，奥吉，” 妈妈用尽全力低声说。还没等她再说别的，塔什曼先生就打开了他办公室的门。“进来吧，孩子们，” 他说，接着走进来两个男孩和一个女孩。他们谁也没看我或妈妈：他们站在门口，直直地看着塔什曼先生，好像他们的生命都取决于此似的。

vocab.ex: The tall man had to lean down to hear what the child was saying.
She pushed the heavy door with all her might.
The door is open, please come on in!
Our picnic plan will depend on the weather.
She spoke softly so as not to wake the baby.
He promised to call me when he got home.
He didn’t even look over when she entered the room.
She walked in quietly and sat by the window.

vocab.mean: 信赖；确信（强调某事必然发生）
vocab.ex: If he said he’ll do it, you can depend on it.

gram.name: 状语置于句首引起的倒装
gram.function: 当表示方位的状语（如 here, there, in, out）置于句首时，如果主语是名词，句子通常会使用完全倒装（谓语动词在主语前），以达到生动的叙事效果。'...and in walked two boys and a girl' 强调了“走进来”这个动作。

example.en: Out of the forest came a large bear.
example.cn: 从森林里走出了一只大熊。

gram.constraints: 如果主语是代词，则不倒装（e.g., 'In he walked'）。

paras.en: "Thanks so much for coming, guys—especially since school doesn't start until next month!" said Mr. Tushman. "Have you had a good summer?" All of them nodded but no one said anything. "Great, great," said Mr. Tushman. "So, guys, I wanted you to meet August, who's going to be a new student here this year. August, these guys have been students at Beecher Prep since kindergarten, though, of course, they were in the lowerschool building, but they know all the ins and outs of the middle-school program. And since you're all in the same homeroom, I thought it would be nice if you got to know each other a little before school started. Okay? So, kids, this is August. August, this is Jack Will."
paras.cn: “非常感谢你们能来，伙计们——尤其是在学校下个月才开学的情况下！” 塔什曼先生说。“你们暑假过得好吗？” 他们都点了点头，但没人说话。“很好，很好，” 塔什曼先生说。“那么，伙计们，我想让你们认识一下奥古斯特，他今年将是这里的新生。奥古斯特，这些孩子从幼儿园起就是比彻预备学校的学生了，不过，当然，他们之前是在低年级教学楼，但他们了解初中部项目的所有细节。而且既然你们都在同一个班，我想如果在开学前你们能互相认识一下会很不错。好吗？所以，孩子们，这位是奥古斯特。奥古斯特，这位是杰克·威尔。”

vocab.ex: The audience nodded in agreement with the speaker.
The children in grades 1-4 attend the lowerschool.
After working here for ten years, she knows all the ins and outs of the company.
It takes time to really get to know someone.

vocab.mean: 幼儿园（通常指学前教育的阶段）
vocab.ex: She has been attending kindergarten since she was five years old.

gram.name: since 引导的原因状语从句
gram.function: 用于引出原因，其原因是听者已经知道或显而易见的。'And since you're all in the same homeroom, I thought...' 意思是“因为你们都在同一个班（这是一个已知事实），所以我想...”。

example.en: Since you're not busy, could you help me with this?
example.cn: 既然你不忙，能帮我一下这个吗？

gram.constraints: 'since' 和 'as' 引导的原因从句通常放在句首，语气比 'because' 弱。

paras.en: Jack Will looked at me and put out his hand. When I shook it, he kind of half smiled and said: "Hey," and looked down really fast. "This is Julian," said Mr. Tushman. "Hey," said Julian, and did the same exact thing as Jack Will: took my hand, forced a smile, looked down fast. "And Charlotte," said Mr. Tushman. Charlotte had the blondest hair I've ever seen. She didn't shake my hand but gave me a quick little wave and smiled. "Hi, August. Nice to meet you," she said. "Hi," I said, looking down. She was wearing bright green Crocs.
paras.cn: 杰克·威尔看着我，伸出了手。当我握住它时，他有点半笑不笑地说：“嘿，”然后很快地低下了头。“这位是朱利安，” 塔什曼先生说。“嘿，” 朱利安说，然后做了和杰克·威尔完全一样的事：握住我的手，挤出一个微笑，然后迅速低下头。“还有夏洛特，” 塔什曼先生说。夏洛特有我见过的最金色的头发。她没有和我握手，而是给了我一个快速的小挥手并笑了笑。“嗨，奥古斯特。很高兴认识你，” 她说。“嗨，” 我低着头说。她穿着亮绿色的洞洞鞋。

vocab.ex: He put out his arm to stop the door from closing.
He gave a nervous half smile when he met his new boss.
Although she was sad, she forced a smile for the camera.
She gave me a friendly wave from across the street.
He put out his hand to greet the new student.
He wore bright red shoes to the party.

gram.name: 最高级与现在完成时
gram.pattern: the + superlative + ... + I've ever + past participle
gram.function: 用于强调某物是说话者经历过的“最…”的事物，极大地加强了最高级的语气。'Charlotte had the blondest hair I've ever seen' 强调了头发颜色的极致。

example.en: This is the most delicious cake I've ever tasted.
example.cn: 这是我尝过的最美味的蛋糕。

gram.constraints: 是表达个人极致体验的常用结构。

paras.en: "So," said Mr. Tushman, putting his hands together in a kind of slow clap. "What I thought you guys could do is take August on a little tour of the school. Maybe you could start on the third floor? That's where your homeroom class is going to be: room 301. I think. Mrs. G, is—" "Room 301!" Mrs. Garcia called out from the other room. "Room 301." Mr. Tushman nodded. "And then you can show August the science labs and the computer room. Then work your way down to the library and the performance space on the second floor. Take him to the cafeteria, of course." "Should we take him to the music room?" asked Julian.
paras.cn: “那么，” 塔什曼先生说，双手合在一起，像是在缓慢地拍手。“我想你们可以做的是带奥古斯特简单参观一下学校。也许你们可以从三楼开始？那是你们班级教室所在的地方：301室。我想是。G夫人，是——” “301室！” 加西亚夫人从另一个房间喊道。“301室。” 塔什曼先生点了点头。“然后你们可以带奥古斯特看看科学实验室和电脑室。然后一路向下到二楼的图书馆和表演区。当然，还要带他去餐厅。” “我们应该带他去音乐室吗？” 朱利安问。

vocab.ex: The audience gave the terrible performance a sarcastic slow clap.
He had to call out her name twice before she heard him.
Start at the top of the list and work your way down.
Students eat their lunch in the school cafeteria.

gram.name: 强调句型 (What... is...)
gram.function: 用于强调句子中的某个特定部分。'What I thought you guys could do is take August on a little tour...' 强调了他想出的“建议”或“计划”的内容。

example.en: What he needs is a good night's sleep.
example.cn: 他需要的是好好睡一觉。

gram.constraints: 由 'what' 引导的主语从句充当句子的主语。

paras.en: "Good idea, yes," said Mr. Tushman. "August, do you play any instruments?" "No," I said. It wasn't my favorite subject on account of the fact that I don't really have ears. Well, I do, but they don't exactly look like normal ears. "Well, you may enjoy seeing the music room anyway," said Mr. Tushman. "We have a very nice selection of percussion instruments." "August, you've been wanting to learn to play the drums," Mom said, trying to get me to look at her. But my eyes were covered by my bangs as I stared at a piece of old gum that was stuck to the bottom of Mr. Tushman's desk.
paras.cn: “好主意，是的，” 塔什曼先生说。“奥古斯特，你玩乐器吗？” “不，” 我说。这不是我最喜欢的科目，原因是我其实没有耳朵。嗯，我有，但它们长得不太像正常的耳朵。“嗯，不管怎样，你也许会喜欢看看音乐室的，” 塔什曼先生说。“我们有非常不错的打击乐器可供选择。” “奥古斯特，你一直都想学打鼓的，” 妈妈说，试图让我看她。但我的眼睛被刘海遮住了，我正盯着粘在塔什曼先生书桌底下的一块旧口香糖。

vocab.ex: The piano is a difficult instrument to learn.

vocab.word: on account of the fact that
vocab.ex: The game was cancelled on account of the fact that it was raining heavily.
Drums, cymbals, and xylophones are all percussion instruments.
She cut her bangs too short by accident.

gram.name: on account of the fact that
gram.pattern: on account of the fact that + clause

components.slot: on account of the fact that

gram.function: 一种非常正式和冗长的表达“因为”的方式，用于引出一个原因状语从句。孩子气的角色使用这种复杂的短语，与他简单的理由（'I don't really have ears'）形成一种有趣的反差。

example.en: He was given a promotion on account of the fact that he had worked harder than anyone else.
example.cn: 他得到了晋升，因为他比任何人都更努力工作。

gram.constraints: 在大多数情况下，使用简单的 'because' 会更自然。

paras.en: "Great! Okay, so why don't you guys get going?" said Mr. Tushman. "Just be back here in . . ." He looked at Mom. "Half an hour, okay?" I think Mom nodded. "So, is that okay with you, August?" he asked me. I didn't answer. "Is that okay, August?" Mom repeated. I looked at her now. I wanted her to see how mad I was at her. But then I saw her face and just nodded. She seemed more scared than I was.
paras.cn: “太好了！好吧，那你们为什么还不出发呢？” 塔什曼先生说。“只要在......回来就行” 他看着妈妈。“半小时，好吗？” 我想妈妈点了点头。“那么，你觉得可以吗，奥古斯特？” 他问我。我没有回答。“可以吗，奥古斯特？” 妈妈重复道。我现在看着她。我想让她看到我有多生她的气。但接着我看到了她的脸，就只是点了点头。她看起来比我还害怕。

vocab.ex: It's getting late, we should get going.
Could you repeat the question, please?
Please don't be mad at me for being late.
The little boy was scared of the dark.

gram.name: Why don't you...? (用于提建议)
gram.function: 虽然形式上是问句，但实际上是用来提出一个温和的建议或指令。'why don't you guys get going?' 是一种比直接命令 'Get going!' 更委婉的说法。

example.en: You look tired. Why don't you take a break?
example.cn: 你看起来很累。为什么不休息一下呢？

gram.constraints: 是一种常见的非正式建议方式。

paras.en: The other kids had started out the door, so I followed them. "See you soon," said Mom, her voice sounding a little higher than normal. I didn't answer her.
paras.cn: 其他的孩子们已经开始走出门口，于是我跟着他们。“待会见，” 妈妈说，她的声音听起来比平时高了一点。我没有回答她。

vocab.ex: We need to start out early tomorrow to avoid traffic.
The ducklings followed their mother to the pond.
His temperature was a little higher than normal, so he stayed home.

gram.name: 独立主格结构（含分词）
gram.function: 在句子中作状语，提供附加的细节或伴随情况，其逻辑主语与主句主语不同。'...her voice sounding a little higher than normal' 描述了妈妈说话时的一种伴随状态，暗示了她的紧张。

example.en: He waited for his friend, his heart beating fast with anticipation.
example.cn: 他等着他的朋友，心里因期待而怦怦直跳。

gram.constraints: 它在语法上独立于主句，通常用逗号隔开。

paras.en: Jack Will, Julian, Charlotte, and I went down a big hallway to some wide stairs. No one said a word as we walked up to the third floor. When we got to the top of the stairs, we went down a little hallway full of lots of doors. Julian opened the door marked 301.
paras.cn: 杰克·威尔、朱利安、夏洛特和我走过一条大走廊，来到一些宽阔的楼梯前。我们走上三楼时，谁也没说一句话。到了楼梯顶端，我们走过一条满是门的小走廊。朱利安打开了标有301的门。

vocab.ex: The students rushed down the hallway to their next class.
Be careful when you walk down the old, creaky stairs.
Follow the path marked with yellow arrows.

gram.name: 表示移动的介词
gram.function: 用于描述动作的方向和路径。'went down a big hallway', 'walked up to the third floor', 'got to the top' 等介词短语清晰地描绘了人物在学校里的行进路线。

example.en: He walked across the bridge and into the city.
example.cn: 他走过桥，进入了城市。

gram.constraints: 介词的选择决定了动作的方向。

paras.en: "This is our homeroom," he said, standing in front of the half-opened door. "We have Ms. Petosa. They say she's okay, at least for homeroom. I heard she's really strict if you get her for math, though." "That's not true," said Charlotte. "My sister had her last year and said she's totally nice." "Not what I heard," answered Julian, "but whatever." He closed the door and continued walking down the hallway.
paras.cn: “这是我们的班级教室，” 他说，站在半开的门前。“我们的班主任是佩托萨女士。他们说她还行，至少当班主任还行。不过，我听说如果数学课是她教，她会非常严格。” “那不是真的，” 夏洛特说。“我姐姐去年就是她教的，说她人超好。” “我听到的可不是这样，” 朱利安回答，“但无所谓了。” 他关上门，继续沿着走廊走下去。

vocab.ex: All students should report to their homeroom at 8 a.m.
He peeked through the half-opened curtain.
The new manager is known for being very strict.
You don't like my idea? Whatever, I'll do it myself.

gram.name: 间接引语 (They say...)
gram.function: 用于转述普遍的看法或传闻，说话者不明确指出信息来源。“They say she's okay” 意思是“据说她还行”，表达的是一种不确定的、道听途说的信息。

example.en: They say it's going to be a very cold winter this year.
example.cn: 据说今年的冬天会非常冷。

gram.constraints: 是一种非正式的信息引用方式。

paras.en: "This is the science lab," he said when he got to the next door. And just like he did two seconds ago, he stood in front of the half-opened door and started talking. He didn't look at me once while he talked, which was okay because I wasn't looking at him, either. "You won't know who you have for science until the first day of school, but you want to get Mr. Haller. He used to be in the lower school. He would play this giant tuba in class." "It was a baritone horn," said Charlotte. "It was a tuba!" answered Julian, closing the door.
paras.cn: “这是科学实验室，” 他走到下一扇门时说。就像他两秒钟前做的那样，他站在半开的门前开始说话。他说话的时候一次也没看我，不过没关系，因为我也没有看他。“直到开学第一天你才会知道你的科学老师是谁，但你会希望是哈勒先生。他以前在小学部。他过去常在课堂上吹一个巨大的大号。” “那是个上低音号，” 夏洛特说。“就是个大号！” 朱利安回答，关上了门。

vocab.ex: We did an experiment in the science lab today.
He didn't thank me once for all my help.
The tuba provides the deep bass notes in the orchestra.
The baritone horn has a softer sound than a trombone.

gram.name: not... until... 结构
gram.function: 表示“直到…才…”，强调某个动作只有在特定时间点之后才会发生。“You won't know... until the first day of school” 强调了信息揭晓的时间。

example.en: I didn't finish my homework until midnight.
example.cn: 我直到午夜才完成我的作业。

variants: It is not until... that... (强调句)
gram.constraints: 主句使用否定形式。

paras.en: "Dude, let him go inside so he can check it out," Jack Will told him, pushing past Julian and opening the door. "Go inside if you want," Julian said. It was the first time he looked at me. I shrugged and walked over to the door. Julian moved out of the way quickly, like he was afraid I might accidentally touch him as I passed by him.
paras.cn: “老兄，让他进去看看吧，” 杰克·威尔对他说，推开朱利安并打开了门。“你想进就进去吧，” 朱利安说。这是他第一次看我。我耸了耸肩，朝门口走去。朱利安迅速地让开了路，好像生怕我路过时会不小心碰到他似的。

vocab.ex: Hey dude, what's up?
There's a new coffee shop on the corner; let's go check it out.
When I asked him where the money was, he just shrugged.
I accidentally broke my mother's favorite vase.

gram.name: 使役动词 (let sb do sth)
gram.function: 表示“让/允许某人做某事”。'...let him go inside...' 是一个建议，意思是“让他进去”。

example.en: My parents let me stay up late on weekends.
example.cn: 我父母允许我周末晚睡。

gram.constraints: 在主动语态中，let, make, have 后面跟不带 to 的不定式作宾补。

paras.en: "Nothing much to see," Julian said, walking in after me. He started pointing to a bunch of stuff around the room. "That's the incubator. That big black thing is the chalkboard. These are the desks. These are chairs. Those are the Bunsen burners. This is a gross science poster. This is chalk. This is the eraser." "I'm sure he knows what an eraser is," Charlotte said, sounding a little like Via. "How would I know what he knows?" Julian answered. "Mr. Tushman said he's never been to a school before."
paras.cn: “没什么好看的，” 朱利安跟着我走进来时说。他开始指着房间里的各种东西。“那是培养箱。那个大黑东西是黑板。这些是书桌。这些是椅子。那些是本生灯。这是一张恶心的科学海报。这是粉笔。这是橡皮擦。” “我敢肯定他知道什么是橡皮擦，” 夏洛特说，听起来有点像维娅。“我怎么会知道他知道什么？” 朱利安回答。“塔什曼先生说他以前从未上过学。”

vocab.ex: Scientists use an incubator to grow cell cultures.
We used a Bunsen burner in the chemistry lab to heat the solution.
There was a dead spider on the wall, it was so gross.
Can I borrow your eraser? I made a mistake.
The teacher wrote the lesson on the chalkboard.
She pointed to the correct answer on the board.

vocab.mean: 本生灯（实验室用来加热、消毒或燃烧的燃气装置）
vocab.ex: The students carefully adjusted the Bunsen burners during the chemistry experiment.

gram.name: 指示代词 (This/That/These/Those)
gram.function: 用于指代特定的物体。'This/These' 指近处的，'That/Those' 指远处的。Julian反复使用这些最基础的指示代词来介绍房间里的物品，这种过度简化的方式带有一种居高临下的、侮辱性的意味。

example.en: This is my book, and that is your pen.
example.cn: 这是我的书，那是你的笔。

gram.constraints: 单复数形式需要与所指代的物体匹配。

paras.en: "You know what an eraser is, right?" Charlotte asked me. I admit I was feeling so nervous that I didn't know what to say or do except look at the floor. "Hey, can you talk?" asked Jack Will. "Yeah." I nodded. I still really hadn't looked at any of them yet, not directly. "You know what an eraser is, right?" asked Jack Will. "Of course!" I mumbled.
paras.cn: “你知道什么是橡皮擦，对吧？” 夏洛特问我。我承认我当时紧张得不知道该说什么或做什么，只能看着地板。“嘿，你会说话吗？” 杰克·威尔问。“会。” 我点了点头。我仍然没有真正看过他们中的任何一个，没有直视过。“你知道什么是橡皮擦，对吧？” 杰克·威尔问。“当然！” 我咕哝道。

vocab.ex: Everyone was at the party except for him.
Please look at me directly when you are speaking.
He tends to mumble when he's nervous, so it's hard to hear him.

gram.name: so... that... 结果状语从句
gram.function: 用于强调程度之深以至于产生了某种结果。'I was feeling so nervous that I didn't know what to say...' 强调了紧张的程度及其导致的后果。

example.en: The music was so loud that we couldn't hear each other speak.
example.cn: 音乐声太大了，我们都听不清对方说话。

gram.constraints: 从句'that' 有时在口语中可以省略，但书面语中通常保留。

paras.en: "I have a question . . . ," I said, trying to keep my voice steady. "Um. What exactly is homeroom? Is that like a subject?" "No, that's just your group," explained Charlotte, ignoring Julian's smirk. "It's like where you go when you get to school in the morning and your homeroom teacher takes attendance and stuff like that. In a way, it's your main class even though it's not really a class. I mean, it's a class, but—" "I think he gets it, Charlotte," said Jack Will. "Do you get it?" Charlotte asked me. "Yeah." I nodded at her.
paras.cn: “我有个问题......，” 我说，努力让自己的声音保持平稳。“嗯。班级教室到底是什么？它像一门科目吗？” “不，那只是你的小组，” 夏洛特解释道，无视朱利安的窃笑。“就像你早上到学校后去的地方，你的班主任会点名之类的。在某种程度上，它是你的主课，即使它不算是一门真正的课。我的意思是，它是一门课，但是——” “我想他明白了，夏洛特，” 杰克·威尔说。“你明白了吗？” 夏洛特问我。“嗯。” 我对她点了点头。

vocab.ex: You need a steady hand to paint such fine details.
He couldn't hide the smirk on his face when his rival made a mistake.
The teacher takes attendance at the beginning of every class.
It's a complex joke, so don't worry if you don't get it at first.

vocab.mean: 保持声音稳定（不显得紧张或害怕）
vocab.ex: She tried to keep her voice steady while asking the question.

vocab.mean: 班会课教室；学生早晨集合的班级小组
vocab.ex: Students go to their homeroom to take attendance before classes start.
The teacher takes attendance at the beginning of each class.

gram.name: 破折号（表示打断）
gram.function: 用于表示说话被打断或话语突然中断。'...it's a class, but—' 表明夏洛特的话还没说完就被杰克·威尔打断了。

example.en: "I was just about to tell you—" she began, but the phone rang.
example.cn: “我正要告诉你——” 她开口说，但电话响了。

gram.constraints: 是表现对话动态的有效标点。

paras.en: "Okay, let's get out of here," said Jack Will, walking away. "Wait, Jack, we're supposed to be answering questions," said Charlotte. Jack Will rolled his eyes a little as he turned around. "Do you have any more questions?" he asked. "Um, no," I answered. "Oh, well, actually, yes. Is your name Jack or Jack Will?" "Jack is my first name. Will is my last name." "Oh, because Mr. Tushman introduced you as Jack Will, so I thought . . ." "Ha! You thought his name was Jackwill!" laughed Julian.
paras.cn: “好了，我们离开这里吧，” 杰克·威尔说着走开了。“等等，杰克，我们应该回答问题的，” 夏洛特说。杰克·威尔转过身时翻了个小白眼。“你还有其他问题吗？” 他问。“嗯，没有了，” 我回答。“哦，嗯，其实，有的。你的名字是叫杰克还是杰克·威尔？” “杰克是我的名。威尔是我的姓。” “哦，因为塔什曼先生介绍你时说的是杰克·威尔，所以我以为......” “哈！你以为他叫杰克威尔！” 朱利安大笑道。

vocab.ex: You were supposed to finish your homework before watching TV.

vocab.mean: 翻白眼（表示不耐烦或不屑）
vocab.ex: She rolled her eyes when her brother started telling another one of his boring stories.
In many Western cultures, people are often called by their first name.
Please write your full last name on the form.

gram.name: 省略号（表示话语未完）
gram.function: 用于表示说话者的话没有说完，可能是因为犹豫、被打断或让听者自己去领会。'...so I thought...' 表明奥吉因为尴尬或被打断而没有把话说完。

example.en: "I was just wondering if maybe..." he said, his voice trailing off.
example.cn: “我只是在想也许……” 他说，声音渐渐弱了下去。

gram.constraints: 在对话中很常见。

paras.en: "Yeah, some people call me by my first and last name," Jack said, shrugging. "I don't know why. Anyway, can we go now?" "Let's go to the performance space next," said Charlotte, leading the way out of the science room. "It's very cool. You'll like it, August."
paras.cn: “是啊，有些人会用我的名和姓一起叫我，” 杰克耸着肩说。“我不知道为什么。总之，我们现在能走了吗？” “我们接下来去表演区吧，” 夏洛特说，带头走出了科学室。“那里很酷。你会喜欢的，奥古斯特。”

vocab.mean: 总之；不管怎样（用于转换话题或回到主题）
vocab.ex: I'm not sure if it will work, but let's try it anyway.
The school built a new performance space for plays and concerts.
Follow me, I'll lead the way to the library.

gram.name: 祈使句 (Let's)
gram.function: 用于提出建议，邀请对方一起做某事。'Let's go to the performance space next' 是夏洛特提出的一个建议。

example.en: It's getting late. Let's go home.
example.cn: 天晚了。我们回家吧。

gram.constraints: Let's 后面必须跟动词原形。

paras.en: Charlotte basically didn't stop talking as we headed down to the second floor. She was describing the play they had put on last year, which was Oliver! She played Oliver even though she's a girl. As she said this, she pushed open the double doors to a huge auditorium. At the other end of the room was a stage.
paras.cn: 我们下到二楼时，夏洛特基本上没停过嘴。她在描述他们去年上演的戏剧，是《雾都孤儿》！尽管她是个女孩，她却扮演了奥利弗。说着这话，她推开了一扇通往巨大礼堂的双开门。在房间的另一头是一个舞台。

vocab.ex: He's a nice guy, basically, but he can be a bit moody.
The local theater group is going to put on a Shakespeare play.
The school's graduation ceremony was held in the auditorium.
The actor walked onto the stage to receive his award.
She pushed open the double doors to enter the auditorium.

gram.name: 使用 'as' 表示同步动作
gram.function: 用于连接两个同时发生的动作，意为“一边…一边…”。'As she said this, she pushed open the double doors...' 描述了说话和推门两个动作是同时进行的。

example.en: As he walked down the street, he whistled a happy tune.
example.cn: 他一边沿着街道走，一边吹着快乐的曲调。

gram.constraints: 强调动作的同步性。

paras.en: Charlotte started skipping toward the stage. Julian ran after her, and then turned around halfway down the aisle. "Come on!" he said loudly, waving for me to follow him, which I did. "There were like hundreds of people in the audience that night," said Charlotte, and it took me a second to realize she was still talking about Oliver! "I was so, so nervous. I had so many lines, and I had all these songs to sing. It was so, so, so, so hard!"
paras.cn: 夏洛特开始蹦蹦跳跳地朝舞台跑去。朱利安追着她跑，然后在过道中途转过身来。“快来！” 他大声说，挥手让我跟他走，我照做了。“那天晚上观众席上大概有几百人，” 夏洛特说，我花了一秒钟才意识到她还在谈论《雾都孤儿》！“我当时特别、特别紧张。我有那么多台词，还有所有这些歌要唱。那真是太、太、太、太难了！”

vocab.ex: The little girl was skipping happily through the park.

vocab.mean: （剧院、教堂、火车等座位间的）过道
vocab.ex: The bride walked gracefully down the aisle.
The audience applauded loudly at the end of the show.
The actor forgot his lines in the middle of the play.

gram.name: which 指代整个动作
gram.function: 在非限定性定语从句中，'which' 可以指代前面整个主句所描述的动作。'...waving for me to follow him, which I did' 中的 'which' 指代的是 'follow him' 这个动作，'which I did' 是一种简洁的说法，表示“我照做了”。

example.en: He asked me to wait, which I did for over an hour.
example.cn: 他让我等，我照做了，等了一个多小时。

gram.constraints: 必须用逗号与主句隔开。

paras.en: Although she was talking to me, she really didn't look at me much. "On opening night, my parents were all the way in back of the auditorium, like where Jack is right now, but when the lights are off, you can't really see that far back. So I was like, 'Where are my parents? Where are my parents?' And then Mr. Resnick, our theater-arts teacher last year—he said: 'Charlotte, stop being such a diva!' And I was like, 'Okay!' And then I spotted my parents and I was totally fine. I didn't forget a single line."
paras.cn: 尽管她是在对我说话，但她其实没怎么看我。“首演那晚，我父母在礼堂最后面，就像杰克现在在的位置，但是当灯关掉后，你其实看不清那么后面。所以我当时就想：‘我爸妈在哪儿？我爸妈在哪儿？’ 然后雷斯尼克先生，我们去年的戏剧艺术老师——他说：‘夏洛特，别那么耍大牌！’ 然后我就想：‘好吧！’ 接着我看到了我父母，就完全没事了。我一句台词也没忘。”

vocab.ex: The cast was very nervous on opening night.
We had to drive all the way to the other side of town.

vocab.mean: 耍大牌的人；歌剧女主角
vocab.ex: He's known for being a bit of a diva and is difficult to work with.
Can you spot the difference between these two pictures?
She took theater-arts classes to improve her acting skills.

gram.name: be like (用于引述)
gram.function: 在非正式的口语叙事中，'be like' 是一种非常常见的用法，用来引述某人说过的话或当时内心的想法。它比 'said' 或 'thought' 更具对话感和即时性。

example.en: And then my friend was like, 'No way!'
example.cn: 然后我朋友就说：‘不可能！’

gram.constraints: 主要用于非正式口语和模仿口语的写作中。

paras.en: While she was talking, I noticed Julian staring at me out of the corner of his eye. This is something I see people do a lot with me. They think I don't know they're staring, but I can tell from the way their heads are tilted. I turned around to see where Jack had gone to. He had stayed in the back of the auditorium, like he was bored.
paras.cn: 她说话的时候，我注意到朱利安用眼角余光盯着我。这是我经常看到人们对我做的事。他们以为我不知道他们在偷看，但我能从他们头倾斜的方式看出来。我转过身去看杰克去哪了。他一直待在礼堂后面，好像很无聊的样子。

vocab.word: out of the corner of one's eye
vocab.ph: /aʊt əv ðə ˈkɔːrnər əv wʌnz aɪ/
vocab.ex: She saw someone following her out of the corner of her eye.
I can tell you're not happy by the look on your face.
He tilted his head to one side, listening carefully.
If you're bored, why don't you read a book?

gram.name: 感官动词结构 (notice sb doing sth)
gram.function: 表示“注意到某人正在做某事”，强调动作的正在进行。'I noticed Julian staring...' 意味着注意到了“盯着看”这个持续的动作。

example.en: I noticed him looking at the clock impatiently.
example.cn: 我注意到他不耐烦地看着时钟。

variants: notice + object + infinitive (注意到动作的全过程或完成)
gram.constraints: 适用于 see, hear, notice, watch, feel 等感官动词。

paras.en: "We put on a play every year," said Charlotte. "I don't think he's going to want to be in the school play, Charlotte," said Julian sarcastically. "You can be in the play without actually being 'in' the play," Charlotte answered, looking at me. "You can do the lighting. You can paint the backdrops." "Oh yeah, whoopee," said Julian, twirling his finger in the air.
paras.cn: “我们每年都上演一出戏，” 夏洛特说。“夏洛特，我不认为他会想参加学校戏剧的，” 朱利安讽刺地说。“你可以参与戏剧，而不必真的‘在’戏里演，” 夏洛特看着我回答。“你可以负责灯光。你可以画背景幕布。” “哦是啊，太棒了，” 朱利安说，手指在空中打着转。

vocab.ex: When I arrived late, he sarcastically said, 'Nice of you to join us.'
The lighting in the theater was dramatic and beautiful.
The students helped paint the backdrops for the school play.
More homework? Oh, whoopee.
The little girl loved to twirl in her new dress.
The school put on a play for the end-of-year celebration.

gram.name: 反讽
gram.pattern: Saying the opposite of what you mean.
gram.function: 通过说出与真实意图相反的话来表达嘲讽或不屑。Julian 说的 'whoopee'（本意是高兴）配合他“手指打转”的动作，清晰地表达了他对这个提议的轻蔑。

example.en: You dropped your ice cream? Great job!
example.cn: 你把冰淇淋掉了？干得漂亮！

gram.constraints: 理解反讽需要依赖上下文、语气和非语言线索。

paras.en: "But you don't have to take the theater-arts elective if you don't want to," Charlotte said, shrugging. "There's dance or chorus or band. There's leadership." "Only dorks take leadership," Julian interrupted. "Julian, you're being so obnoxious!" said Charlotte, which made Julian laugh.
paras.cn: “但如果你不想，你不必选戏剧艺术这门选修课，” 夏洛特耸着肩说。“还有舞蹈、合唱或乐队。还有领导力课。” “只有呆子才选领导力，” 朱利安打断道。“朱利安，你真是太讨厌了！” 夏洛特说，这句话让朱利安笑了。

vocab.ex: She has a beautiful voice and sings in the school chorus.
The course is designed to develop students' leadership skills.
He called me a dork just because I like reading comic books.
His loud and obnoxious behavior made everyone uncomfortable.
I chose art as my elective this semester.

vocab.mean: 耸肩（表示无所谓或不确定）
vocab.ex: She shrugged when asked about her weekend plans.

gram.name: 现在进行时（用于描述暂时行为）
gram.function: 用于描述某人此刻表现出的、暂时的行为或态度，而不是其一贯的性格。'you're being so obnoxious' 意思是“你现在的行为很讨厌”，而不是说“你本质上是个讨厌的人”。

example.en: Why are you being so quiet today? Are you okay?
example.cn: 你今天怎么这么安静？你还好吗？

gram.constraints: 通常用于描述可以受主观控制的行为，不适用于描述无法控制的状态（如 tall, old）。

paras.en: "I'm taking the science elective," I said. "Cool!" said Charlotte. Julian looked directly at me. "The science elective is supposably the hardest elective of all," he said. "No offense, but if you've never, ever been in a school before, why do you think you're suddenly going to be smart enough to take the science elective? I mean, have you ever even studied science before? Like real science, not like the kind you do in kits?"
paras.cn: “我选科学选修课，” 我说。“酷！” 夏洛特说。朱利安直视着我。“科学选修课据说是所有选修课中最难的，” 他说。“无意冒犯，但如果你以前从来没有上过学，你为什么会认为你突然就聪明到可以选科学选修课了？我的意思是，你以前学过科学吗？比如真正的科学，而不是那种你在工具套装里做的那种？”

vocab.ex: You won the first prize? Cool!
This word is often considered an error for 'supposedly'.
No offense, but that's not a very good idea.
He built a model airplane from a kit.

gram.name: 话语标记 (No offense, but...)
gram.function: 用于在说出可能冒犯或批评他人的话之前，试图减轻其攻击性。然而，它通常预示着后面将要说的确实是冒犯性的话。

example.en: No offense, but I think you're making a mistake.
example.cn: 无意冒犯，但我认为你正在犯一个错误。

gram.constraints: 是一种常见的口语策略。

paras.en: "Yeah." I nodded. "He was homeschooled, Julian!" said Charlotte. "So teachers came to his house?" asked Julian, looking puzzled. "No, his mother taught him!" answered Charlotte. "Is she a teacher?" Julian said. "Is your mother a teacher?" Charlotte asked me. "No," I said. "So she's not a real teacher!" said Julian, as if that proved his point. "That's what I mean. How can someone who's not a real teacher actually teach science?"
paras.cn: “是的。” 我点了点头。“他是在家上学的，朱利安！” 夏洛特说。“所以是老师到他家来？” 朱利安问，看起来很困惑。“不，是他妈妈教他！” 夏洛特回答。“她是个老师吗？” 朱利安说。“你妈妈是老师吗？” 夏洛特问我。“不，” 我说。“所以她不是真正的老师！” 朱利安说，好像那证明了他的观点似的。“我就是这个意思。一个不是真正老师的人怎么能真正教科学呢？”

vocab.ex: More and more parents are choosing to have their children homeschooled.
She had a puzzled expression on her face.
He used statistics and charts to prove his point during the debate.

gram.name: as if / as though 从句
gram.function: 用于引出一个方式状语从句，进行比喻或描述看起来像的情景，意为“好像；仿佛”。'...as if that proved his point' 描述了朱利安说话时的神态，好像他已经赢得了辩论。

example.en: He talks as if he knows everything.
example.cn: 他说话的口气好像他什么都知道似的。

gram.constraints: 当描述与事实相反的假设时，从句中常使用虚拟语气（如 'as if he were...'）。

paras.en: "I'm sure you'll do fine," said Charlotte, looking at me. "Let's just go to the library now," Jack called out, sounding really bored. "Why is your hair so long?" Julian said to me. He sounded like he was annoyed. I didn't know what to say, so I just shrugged. "Can I ask you a question?" he said. I shrugged again. Didn't he just ask me a question?
paras.cn: “我相信你会做得很好的，” 夏洛特看着我说。“我们现在就去图书馆吧，” 杰克喊道，听起来真的很无聊。“你的头发为什么这么长？” 朱利安对我说。他听起来像是很烦躁。我不知道该说什么，所以只是耸了耸肩。“我能问你一个问题吗？” 他说。我又耸了耸肩。他不是刚问了我一个问题吗？

vocab.ex: Don't worry about the test; I'm sure you'll do fine.
He had to call out her name twice before she heard him.
She was annoyed by the constant noise from the construction site.
When I asked him where the money was, he just shrugged.

gram.name: 反问句（用于内心思考）
gram.function: 说话者提出一个问题，但并不期望得到回答，而是用来表达自己的思考、惊讶或讽刺。'Didn't he just ask me a question?' 是主角内心的吐槽，表达了他对朱利安问题的困惑和觉得其多此一举。

example.en: He told me to hurry up, and then spent ten minutes looking for his keys. Isn't that ironic?
example.cn: 他让我快点，然后自己花了十分钟找钥匙。这难道不讽刺吗？

gram.constraints: 其功能是表达观点，而非获取信息。

paras.en: "What's the deal with your face? I mean, were you in a fire or something?" "Julian, that's so rude!" said Charlotte. "I'm not being rude," said Julian, "I'm just asking a question. Mr. Tushman said we could ask questions if we wanted to." "Not rude questions like that," said Charlotte. "Besides, he was born like that. That's what Mr. Tushman said. You just weren't listening." "I was so listening!" said Julian. "I just thought maybe he was in a fire, too." "Geez, Julian," said Jack. "Just shut up." "You shut up!" Julian yelled.
paras.cn: “你的脸是怎么回事？我的意思是，你被火烧过还是怎么了？” “朱利安，那太无礼了！” 夏洛特说。“我没有无礼，” 朱利安说，“我只是问个问题。塔什曼先生说如果我们想，可以问问题。” “不是像那样无礼的问题，” 夏洛特说。“而且，他生来就是那样的。塔什曼先生是这么说的。你根本就没在听。” “我明明就在听！” 朱利安说。“我只是以为他可能也被火烧过。” “天哪，朱利安，” 杰克说。“闭嘴吧。” “你才闭嘴！” 朱利安吼道。

vocab.ex: What's the deal with all this traffic? We're going to be late.
It's rude to ask someone how much money they make.
I don't want to go to the party. Besides, I'm too tired.

vocab.mean: （表示惊讶、懊恼的感叹词）天哪
vocab.ex: Geez, I can't believe you forgot my birthday!
His parents told him to shut up, but he kept talking.

gram.name: 过去进行时（用于强调）
gram.function: 除了表示过去正在进行的动作，过去进行时也可以用来反驳或强烈肯定某个动作在当时确实发生了。'I was so listening!' 强调了“我当时真的在听”，用来反驳夏洛特说的 'You just weren't listening'。

example.en: A: You didn't call me last night! B: I was calling you! You just didn't pick up.
example.cn: A：你昨晚没给我打电话！B：我打了！只是你没接。

gram.constraints: 通过重读 'was' 或添加 'so' 来加强语气。

paras.en: "Come on, August," said Jack. "Let's just go to the library already." I walked toward Jack and followed him out of the auditorium. He held the double doors open for me, and as I passed by, he looked at me right in the face, kind of daring me to look back at him, which I did. Then I actually smiled. I don't know. Sometimes when I have the feeling like I'm almost crying, it can turn into an almost-laughing feeling. And that must have been the feeling I was having then, because I smiled, almost like I was going to giggle. The thing is, because of the way my face is, people who don't know me very well don't always get that I'm smiling. My mouth doesn't go up at the corners the way other people's mouths do. It just goes straight across my face. But somehow Jack Will got that I had smiled at him. And he smiled back.
paras.cn: “走吧，奥古斯特，” 杰克说。“我们现在就去图书馆吧。” 我朝杰克走去，跟着他走出了礼堂。他为我扶着双开门，当我经过时，他直视着我的脸，有点像在挑战我回看他，我照做了。然后我居然笑了。我不知道。有时候当我感觉快要哭出来时，那种感觉会转变成一种快要笑出来的感觉。我那时一定就是那种感觉，因为我笑了，几乎就像要咯咯笑一样。问题是，因为我脸的样子，不太了解我的人不总能明白我是在笑。我的嘴不会像别人的嘴那样嘴角上扬。它只是横贯我的脸。但不知何故，杰克·威尔明白了我在对他笑。他也回以微笑。

vocab.mean: （用于句末，表示不耐烦）快点吧
vocab.ex: Hurry up and finish your dinner already!
His friends dared him to jump into the cold lake.
The two girls started to giggle during the quiet movie.
I explained it three times, but he still didn't get that I was joking.
He gave me a daring look, challenging me to answer.
I had an almost-laughing expression when I heard the joke.
Her smile reached the corners of her mouth.

gram.name: the way + 从句
gram.function: 用于引出一个方式状语从句，意为“以…的方式”。'My mouth doesn't go up at the corners the way other people's mouths do' 比较了“我的嘴”和“别人的嘴”上扬方式的不同。

example.en: She sings the way a professional singer does.
example.cn: 她唱歌的方式就像一个专业歌手。

gram.constraints: 是一种常见的比较方式的表达。

paras.en: "Julian's a jerk," he whispered before Julian and Charlotte reached us. "But, dude, you're gonna have to talk." He said this seriously, like he was trying to help me. I nodded as Julian and Charlotte caught up to us. We were all quiet for a second, all of us just kind of nodding, looking at the floor. Then I looked up at Julian. "The word's 'supposedly,' by the way," I said. "What are you talking about?" "You said 'supposably' before," I said. "I did not!" "Yeah you did," Charlotte nodded. "You said the science elective is supposably really hard. I heard you." "I absolutely did not," he insisted.
paras.cn: “朱利安是个混蛋，” 他在朱利安和夏洛特赶上我们之前低声说。“但是，哥们，你得说话才行。” 他严肃地说了这番话，好像在试图帮助我。我点了点头，这时朱利安和夏洛特赶上了我们。我们都安静了一会儿，都有点点头，看着地板。然后我抬头看着朱利安。“顺便说一下，那个词是‘supposedly’，” 我说。“你在说什么？” “你刚才说了‘supposably’，” 我说。“我没有！” “是，你说了，” 夏洛特点了点头。“你说科学选修课‘supposably’很难。我听到了。” “我绝对没有，” 他坚持说。

vocab.ex: Don't be such a jerk to your little sister.
I'm gonna be late for my appointment.
You walk too fast; I can't catch up to you.
Supposedly, the new movie is very good.
He kept insisting he was right, even when we showed him the evidence.

gram.name: have to (表示必要性)
gram.function: 表示客观上的“必须”或“不得不”。'you're gonna have to talk' (you are going to have to talk) 是杰克给奥吉的建议，指出说话是他在学校生存下去的必要条件。

example.en: I have to finish this report by 5 p.m.
example.cn: 我必须在下午5点前完成这份报告。

gram.constraints: 'have to' 更多指外部要求，而 'must' 更多指主观意愿。

paras.en: "Whatever," said Jack. "Let's just go." "Yeah, let's just go," agreed Charlotte, following Jack down the stairs to the next floor. I started to follow her, but Julian cut right in front of me, which actually made me stumble backward. "Oops, sorry about that!" said Julian. But I could tell from the way he looked at me that he wasn't really sorry at all.
paras.cn: “无所谓了，” 杰克说。“我们走吧。” “是啊，我们走吧，” 夏洛特同意道，跟着杰克下楼去下一层。我开始跟着她，但朱利安直接插到我前面，这真的让我向后踉跄了一下。“哎呀，不好意思！” 朱利安说。但我能从他看我的眼神中看出，他根本就不是真的抱歉。

vocab.ex: You don't like my idea? Whatever, I'll do it myself.
It's rude to cut in front of people in a line.
He stumbled on the uneven pavement and nearly fell.
Oops, I spilled some water on your book.

gram.name: I could tell from...
gram.function: 表示“我能从…中看出…”，用于解释自己做出某个判断所依据的线索或证据。'I could tell from the way he looked at me that...' 表明主角是通过观察朱利安的眼神来判断他真实意图的。

example.en: I could tell from her voice that she was very excited.
example.cn: 我能从她的声音中听出她非常兴奋。

gram.constraints: 'that' 引导的宾语从句可以被省略。

paras.en: Mom and Mr. Tushman were talking when we got back to the office. Mrs. Garcia was the first to see us come back, and she started smiling her shiny smile as we walked in. "So, August, what did you think? Did you like what you saw?" she asked. "Yeah." I nodded, looking over at Mom. Jack, Julian, and Charlotte were standing by the door, not sure where to go or if they were still needed. I wondered what else they'd been told about me before they'd met me.
paras.cn: 我们回到办公室时，妈妈和塔什曼先生正在谈话。加西亚夫人是第一个看到我们回来的，当我们走进来时，她开始露出她那亮晶晶的微笑。“那么，奥古斯特，你觉得怎么样？你喜欢你看到的吗？” 她问。“嗯。” 我点点头，朝妈妈那边看去。杰克、朱利安和夏洛特正站在门口，不确定该去哪里，或者是否还需要他们。我想知道在他们见到我之前，他们还被告知了关于我的其他什么事。

vocab.mean: 亮晶晶的微笑（指虚假的、职业性的微笑）
vocab.ex: The salesperson greeted me with a shiny smile that didn't seem genuine.
After the party, I stayed to help clean up because I felt I was still needed.
I wonder what time the movie starts tonight.

gram.name: 过去进行时（设置背景）
gram.function: 用于描述在过去某个时间点正在进行的背景动作。'Mom and Mr. Tushman were talking' 和 'Jack, Julian, and Charlotte were standing' 描述了当“我们回来时”正在发生的情景。

example.en: It was raining heavily when I left the house.
example.cn: 我离开家时，雨正下得很大。

gram.constraints: 常与 'when' 或 'while' 引导的另一个过去时动作连用。

paras.en: "Did you see the baby chick?" Mom asked me. As I shook my head, Julian said: "Are you talking about the baby chicks in science? Those get donated to a farm at the end of every school year." "Oh," said Mom, disappointed. "But they hatch new ones every year in science," Julian added. "So August will be able to see them again in the spring." "Oh, good," said Mom, eyeing me. "They were so cute, August." I wished she wouldn't talk to me like I was a baby in front of other people.
paras.cn: “你看到那只小鸡了吗？” 妈妈问我。当我摇头时，朱利安说：“你说的是科学课上的小鸡吗？那些在每个学年末都会被捐赠给一个农场。” “哦，” 妈妈失望地说。“但是他们每年科学课都会孵化新的，” 朱利安补充道。“所以奥古斯特春天时就能再看到了。” “哦，太好了，” 妈妈说着，瞟了我一眼。“它们太可爱了，奥古斯特。” 我希望她不要在别人面前像对婴儿一样跟我说话。

vocab.ex: She decided to donate her old clothes to charity.
He was disappointed that he didn't get the job.
We watched the little turtle hatch from its egg.
The cat was eyeing the bird on the fence.

gram.name: wish + would (表示抱怨或愿望)
gram.function: 用于表达对他人当前行为的抱怨，或希望他人改变其行为。'I wished she wouldn't talk to me like I was a baby' 表达了主角对妈妈当时说话方式的不满。

example.en: I wish you wouldn't play your music so loudly.
example.cn: 我希望你不要把音乐放那么大声。

gram.constraints: 主句和从句的主语通常不相同。

paras.en: "So, August," said Mr. Tushman, "did these guys show you around enough or do you want to see more? I realize I forgot to ask them to show you the gym." "We did anyway, Mr. Tushman," said Julian. "Excellent!" said Mr. Tushman. "And I told him about the school play and some of the electives," said Charlotte. "Oh no!" she said suddenly. "We forgot to show him the art room!" "That's okay," said Mr. Tushman. "But we can show it to him now," Charlotte offered.
paras.cn: “那么，奥古斯特，” 塔什曼先生说，“这些孩子带你逛够了吗，还是你想看更多？我意识到我忘了让他们带你看体育馆了。” “我们还是去了，塔什曼先生，” 朱利安说。“太棒了！” 塔什曼先生说。“而且我告诉了他关于学校戏剧和一些选修课的事，” 夏洛特说。“哦不！” 她突然说。“我们忘了带他看美术室了！” “没关系，” 塔什曼先生说。“但我们现在可以带他去看，” 夏洛特主动提议。

vocab.ex: When my cousin visited, I showed him around the city.
It was raining, but we went for a walk anyway.
You finished the project ahead of schedule? Excellent!
He offered to help me with my heavy bags.

gram.name: 不定式链
gram.pattern: Verb + to Verb + Object + to Verb...
gram.function: 当一个动词的宾语是另一个动作时，常常使用不定式。这里形成了 'forgot to ask them to show you' 的链条，清晰地表达了一系列意图和指令。

example.en: I promised to try to get him to come to the party.
example.cn: 我答应了会试着让他来参加派对。

gram.constraints: 动词如 'ask', 'tell', 'want', 'promise', 'forget' 等常用于此类结构。

paras.en: "Don't we have to pick Via up soon?" I said to Mom. That was our signal for my telling Mom if I really wanted to leave. "Oh, you're right," said Mom, getting up. I could tell she was pretending to check the time on her watch. "I'm sorry, everybody. I lost track of the time. We have to go pick up my daughter at her new school. She's taking an unofficial tour today." This part wasn't a lie: that Via was checking out her new school today. The part that was a lie was that we were picking her up at the school, which we weren't. She was coming home with Dad later.
paras.cn: “我们不是很快就要去接维娅了吗？” 我对妈妈说。那是我告诉妈妈我是否真的想离开的暗号。“哦，你说得对，” 妈妈站起来说。我看得出她在假装看手表上的时间。“对不起，各位。我忘了时间了。我们得去新学校接我女儿。她今天正在进行一次非正式的参观。” 这部分不是谎话：维娅今天确实在看她的新学校。谎话的部分是我们要在学校接她，其实我们并不会。她晚些时候会和爸爸一起回家。

vocab.ex: Can you pick me up from the airport tomorrow?
A nod was the signal to begin the performance.
I was so absorbed in my book that I completely lost track of time.
The team had an unofficial meeting after work.

gram.name: 强调句型 (The part that... was...)
gram.pattern: The part that + Verb + was + [emphasized part]
gram.function: 用于将一个复杂情况分解，并清晰地强调其中的某个特定方面。通过 'The part that wasn't a lie...' 和 'The part that was a lie...' 的对比，叙述者精确地区分了陈述中的真话和假话。

example.en: The part that I enjoyed the most was the surprise ending.
example.cn: 我最喜欢的部分是那个惊喜的结局。

gram.constraints: 这是一种清晰化和强调的有效结构。

paras.en: "Where does she go to school?" asked Mr. Tushman, getting up. "She's starting Faulkner High School this fall." "Wow, that's not an easy school to get into. Good for her!" "Thank you," said Mom, nodding. "It'll be a bit of a schlep, though. The A train down to Eighty-Sixth, then the crosstown bus all the way to the East Side. Takes an hour that way but it's just a fifteen-minute drive."
paras.cn: “她在哪里上学？” 塔什曼先生站起来问。“她今年秋天开始上福克纳高中。” “哇，那可不是一所容易进的学校。真为她高兴！” “谢谢您，” 妈妈点着头说。“不过路途会有点折腾。坐A线地铁到86街，然后坐横穿市区的公交车一直到东区。那样要花一个小时，但开车只要十五分钟。”

vocab.ex: He worked hard to get into a good university.
She won the competition? Good for her!
Carrying all those groceries up five flights of stairs was a real schlep.
The crosstown traffic is always terrible during rush hour.

gram.name: 对比时间长度
gram.pattern: It takes [time A]... but it's just [time B]...
gram.function: 通过使用 'It takes...' 结构和转折连词 'but'，清晰地对比了两种不同交通方式所需时间的巨大差异，强调了通勤的“折腾”。

example.en: It takes an hour to get there by bus, but it's only a twenty-minute train ride.
example.cn: 坐公交车去那里要一个小时，但坐火车只要二十分钟。

gram.constraints: 'It takes' 后面跟时间，用于描述完成某事所需的时间。

paras.en: "It'll be worth it. I know a couple of kids who got into Faulkner and love it," said Mr. Tushman. "We should really go, Mom," I said, tugging at her pocketbook. We said goodbye kind of quickly after that. I think Mr. Tushman was a little surprised that we were leaving so suddenly, and then I wondered if he would blame Jack and Charlotte, even though it was really only Julian who made me feel kind of bad. "Everyone was really nice," I made sure to tell Mr. Tushman before we left. "I look forward to having you as a student," said Mr. Tushman, patting my back. "Bye," I said to Jack, Charlotte, and Julian, but I didn't look at them—or look up at all—until I left the building.
paras.cn: “那将是值得的。我认识几个进了福克纳并且很喜欢那里的孩子，” 塔什曼先生说。“我们真的该走了，妈妈，” 我说，拉着她的手提包。那之后我们有点匆忙地道了别。我想塔什曼先生对我们这么突然离开有点惊讶，然后我想知道他是否会责备杰克和夏洛特，尽管真正让我感觉有点糟糕的只有朱利安。“每个人都非常好，” 我在离开前特意告诉塔什曼先生。“我期待你能成为我的学生，” 塔什曼先生拍着我的背说。“再见，” 我对杰克、夏洛特和朱利安说，但我没有看他们——或者说根本没有抬头——直到我离开那栋楼。

vocab.ex: The hike was difficult, but the view from the top was worth it.
The little child was tugging at his mother's sleeve to get her attention.
She couldn't find her keys in her large pocketbook.
Don't blame me for your own mistakes.
Please make sure to lock the door when you leave.
I'm looking forward to seeing you this weekend.

gram.name: look forward to + V-ing/Noun
gram.function: 表示对未来事件的“期待”。这里的 'to' 是介词，所以后面必须跟名词或动名词。'...look forward to having you as a student' 中，'having you as a student' 是一个动名词短语。

example.en: We are looking forward to our vacation next month.
example.cn: 我们正期待着下个月的假期。

gram.constraints: 'to' 是介词，后面不能跟动词原形。

paras.en: As soon as we had walked at least half a block from the school, Mom said: "So . . . how'd it go? Did you like it?" "Not yet, Mom. When we get home," I said. The moment we got inside the house, I ran to my room and threw myself onto my bed. I could tell Mom didn't know what was up, and I guess I really didn't, either. I felt very sad and a tiny bit happy at the exact same time, kind of like that laughing-crying feeling all over again.
paras.cn: 我们一走出学校至少半个街区，妈妈就说：“那么……怎么样？你喜欢那里吗？” “还不是时候，妈妈。等我们到家再说，” 我说。我们一进家门，我就跑到我的房间，把自己扔到床上。我看得出妈妈不知道是怎么回事，我猜我自己也真的不知道。我感到非常难过，同时又有一点点开心，有点像那种又哭又笑的感觉又来了。

vocab.ex: Please call me as soon as you arrive.
You had a job interview today, right? So, how'd it go?
After a long day, he threw himself onto the sofa.
From her sad expression, I knew something was up.
Could you move your chair a tiny bit to the left?

gram.name: 复合形容词 (分词构成)
gram.function: 通过将两个或多个词（此处为现在分词）用连字符连接，创造一个新的、更具描述性的形容词。'laughing-crying feeling' 生动地描绘了一种矛盾、复杂的情感状态。

example.en: It was a bitter-sweet moment when she left for college.
example.cn: 她去上大学时，那是一个苦乐参半的时刻。

gram.constraints: 是一种创造新词的有效方式。

paras.en: My dog, Daisy, followed me into the room, jumped on the bed, and started licking me all over my face. "Who's a good girlie?" I said in my Dad voice. "Who's a good girlie?"
paras.cn: 我的狗黛西跟着我进了房间，跳上床，开始舔我的整张脸。“谁是好女孩呀？” 我用我爸爸的声音说。“谁是好女孩呀？”

vocab.ex: The cat started to lick its paws clean.
After playing in the mud, the dog was dirty all over.

vocab.mean: （对女孩或雌性动物的昵称）小姑娘
vocab.ex: He calls his little daughter his favorite girlie.

gram.name: 同位语（用于指名）
gram.function: 用于对前面的名词进行补充说明，提供其具体名称。'My dog, Daisy, followed me...' 中的 'Daisy' 就是 'My dog' 的同位语。

example.en: My best friend, Sarah, is coming to visit.
example.cn: 我最好的朋友莎拉要来拜访。

gram.constraints: 同位语通常用逗号与句子的其余部分隔开。

paras.en: "Is everything okay, sweetness?" Mom said. She wanted to sit down beside me but Daisy was hogging the bed. "Excuse me, Daisy." She sat down, nudging Daisy over. "Were those kids not nice to you, Auggie?" "Oh no," I said, only half lying. "They were okay." "But were they nice? Mr. Tushman went out of his way to tell me what sweet kids they are." "Uh-huh." I nodded, but I kept looking at Daisy, kissing her on the nose and rubbing her ear until her back leg did that little flea-scratch shake.
paras.cn: “一切都好吗，小甜心？” 妈妈说。她想坐在我旁边，但黛西正霸占着床。“不好意思，黛西。” 她坐了下来，把黛西往旁边推了推。“那些孩子对你不好吗，奥吉？” “哦不，” 我说，只说了一半的谎。“他们还行。” “但是他们友善吗？塔什曼先生特意告诉我他们是多么甜美的孩子。” “嗯哼。” 我点了点头，但我一直看着黛西，亲吻她的鼻子，揉着她的耳朵，直到她的后腿做出那种像挠痒痒一样的抖动。

vocab.ex: "Good morning, sweetness," she said to her daughter.
Don't hog the remote control; let others choose a show.
She gave him a gentle nudge to wake him up.
She really went out of her way to make me feel welcome.
The descriptive term 'flea-scratch shake' creates a vivid image of the dog's reaction.

gram.name: 最高级 (the least)
gram.function: 用于在三者或三者以上的范围内进行比较，表示程度最低，是 'the most' 的反义词。'he was the least nice' 意思是“他是最不友善的那个”。

example.en: Of all the movies I saw this year, that one was the least interesting.
example.cn: 在我今年看的所有电影中，那一部是最没意思的。

gram.constraints: 用于多音节形容词前。

paras.en: "That boy Julian seemed especially nice," Mom said. "Oh, no, he was the least nice. I liked Jack, though. He was nice. I thought his name was Jack Will but it's just Jack." "Wait, maybe I'm getting them confused. Which one was the one with the dark hair that was brushed forward?" "Julian." "And he wasn't nice?" "No, not nice." "Oh." She thought about this for a second. "Okay, so is he the kind of kid who's one way in front of grown-ups and another way in front of kids?" "Yeah, I guess." "Ah, hate those," she answered, nodding.
paras.cn: “那个叫朱利安的男孩似乎特别友善，” 妈妈说。“哦，不，他最不友善了。不过我喜欢杰克。他人很好。我以为他的名字是杰克·威尔，但其实只是杰克。” “等等，也许我把他们搞混了。哪个是那个黑头发、头发往前梳的？” “朱利安。” “他不好吗？” “不，不好。” “哦。” 她想了一会儿。“好吧，那么他是那种在大人面前一个样，在孩子面前另一个样的孩子吗？” “嗯，我猜是。” “啊，讨厌那种，” 她点着头回答。

vocab.ex: I love ice cream, especially the chocolate flavor.
He was the least helpful person in the group.

vocab.mean: 把某人搞糊涂；把（人或物）搞混
vocab.ex: The twins look so alike, I always get them confused.
He's charming in public, but a completely different way at home.

gram.name: 描述对比行为的结构
gram.pattern: ...one way in front of X and another way in front of Y
gram.function: 用于描述某人在不同情境或不同人群面前表现出的截然不同的行为或性格，常用来指“两面派”或虚伪。

example.en: She acts one way with her friends and a completely another way with her parents.
example.cn: 她在朋友面前一个样，在父母面前完全是另一个样。

gram.constraints: 是一种描述人物性格复杂性的有效结构。

paras.en: "He was like, 'So, August, what's the deal with your face?' " I said, looking at Daisy the whole time. " 'Were you in a fire or something?' " Mom didn't say anything. When I looked up at her, I could tell she was completely shocked. "He didn't say it in a mean way," I said quickly. "He was just asking." Mom nodded. "But I really liked Jack," I said. "He was like, 'Shut up, Julian!' And Charlotte was like, 'You're so rude, Julian!' "
paras.cn: “他当时就说：‘那么，奥古斯特，你的脸是怎么回事？’” 我说，全程都看着黛西。“‘你被火烧过还是怎么了？’” 妈妈什么也没说。当我抬头看她时，我看得出她完全震惊了。“他不是恶意说的，” 我赶紧说。“他只是问问。” 妈妈点了点头。“但我真的很喜欢杰克，” 我说。“他当时就说：‘闭嘴，朱利安！’ 夏洛特也说：‘你太无礼了，朱利安！’”

vocab.ex: What's the deal with all this traffic? We're going to be late.
We were all shocked to hear the news.
He didn't intend to be hurtful; he didn't say it in a mean way.
His parents told him to shut up, but he kept talking.

gram.name: I could tell
gram.function: 表示“我看得出”或“我能感觉到”，用于根据观察到的迹象做出推断。'I could tell she was completely shocked' 是叙述者根据妈妈的沉默和表情做出的判断。

example.en: I could tell he was lying from the way he avoided my eyes.
example.cn: 从他躲避我眼神的样子，我看得出他在撒谎。

gram.constraints: 后面通常跟一个由 'that' 引导的宾语从句，'that' 可以省略。

paras.en: Mom nodded again. She pressed her fingers on her forehead like she was pushing against a headache. "I'm so sorry, Auggie," she said quietly. Her cheeks were bright red. "No, it's okay, Mom, really." "You don't have to go to school if you don't want, sweetie." "I want to," I said. "Auggie . . ." "Really, Mom. I want to." And I wasn't lying.
paras.cn: 妈妈又点了点头。她用手指按着额头，好像在抵御头痛。“我太抱歉了，奥吉，” 她轻声说。她的脸颊通红。“不，没事的，妈妈，真的。” “如果你不想，你不用去上学，宝贝。” “我想去，” 我说。“奥吉......” “真的，妈妈。我想去。” 而且我没有撒谎。

vocab.ex: He wiped the sweat from his forehead with the back of his hand.
Loud noise often gives me a headache.
Come here, sweetie, and give me a hug.
I could tell from his expression that he was lying.

gram.name: 责任与愿望的对比 (have to vs. want to)
gram.pattern: don't have to vs. want to
gram.function: 通过对比 'don't have to' (没有义务) 和 'I want to' (我想要)，清晰地展示了主角心态的转变。尽管他可以选择不去（没有外部强迫），但他现在表达了自己内在的、主动的愿望要去。

example.en: You don't have to come to the party, but I really want you to be there.
example.cn: 你不是非得来参加派对，但我真的希望你在场。

gram.constraints: 这是表达选择和意愿的基本且重要的结构。

paras.en: Okay, so I admit that the first day of school I was so nervous that the butterflies in my stomach were more like pigeons flying around my insides. Mom and Dad were probably a little nervous, too, but they acted all excited for me, taking pictures of me and Via before we left the house since it was Via's first day of school, too.
paras.cn: 好吧，我承认开学第一天我紧张得不得了，胃里的蝴蝶更像是鸽子在我体内乱飞。爸爸妈妈可能也有点紧张，但他们为我表现得非常兴奋，在我们离开家之前给我和维娅拍照，因为那天也是维娅开学的第一天。

vocab.ex: He finally had to admit that he had made a mistake.
I always get butterflies in my stomach before giving a presentation.
A flock of pigeons flew up from the city square.
After eating that spicy food, my insides felt like they were on fire.

gram.name: 强化的隐喻
gram.pattern: Taking a common idiom and making it more extreme.
gram.function: 作者没有直接说“我很紧张”，而是先用了常见的习语 'butterflies in my stomach'，然后通过将其升级为更具冲击力的 'pigeons flying around'，创造了一个更强烈、更独特的意象，生动地传达了极度的紧张感。

example.en: It wasn't just raining; it was more like a waterfall coming from the sky.
example.cn: 那不只是下雨，更像是瀑布从天而降。

gram.constraints: 这是一种创造性的写作技巧，用于使描述更生动。

paras.en: Up until a few days before, we still weren't sure I would be going to school at all. After my tour of the school, Mom and Dad had reversed sides on whether I should go or not. Mom was now the one saying I shouldn't go and Dad was saying I should. Dad had told me he was really proud of how I'd handled myself with Julian and that I was turning into quite the strong man. And I heard him tell Mom that he now thought she had been right all along. But Mom, I could tell, wasn't so sure anymore. When Dad told her that he and Via wanted to walk me to school today, too, since it was on the way to the subway station, Mom seemed relieved that we would all be going together. And I guess I was, too.
paras.cn: 直到几天前，我们还不确定我到底会不会去上学。在我参观完学校后，妈妈和爸爸对于我是否应该去上学的立场完全调转了。现在是妈妈说我不应该去，而爸爸说我应该去。爸爸曾告诉我，他为我应对朱利安的方式感到非常骄傲，而且我正在变成一个相当坚强的男子汉。我还听到他告诉妈妈，他现在认为她一直以来都是对的。但我看得出，妈妈不再那么肯定了。当爸爸告诉她，他和维娅今天也想送我上学，因为顺路去地铁站时，妈妈似乎松了口气，因为我们大家可以一起去。我猜我也是。

vocab.ex: Up until last week, I thought the project was due in May.
The two politicians reversed sides on the issue after the new report was published.
She handled herself with great professionalism during the difficult meeting.
I knew the secret all along, but I didn't say anything.

vocab.mean: 松了一口气的；感到宽慰的
vocab.ex: I was so relieved to hear that you were safe.

gram.name: 间接引语
gram.function: 用于转述他人的话语或想法。文中多次使用，如 'Dad had told me he was proud...' 和 'I heard him tell Mom that he now thought...'。注意转述时人称和时态可能发生的变化。

example.en: She said that she was feeling tired.
example.cn: 她说她感觉累了。

gram.constraints: 连词 'that' 常常可以省略。

paras.en: Even though Beecher Prep is just a few blocks from our house, I've only been on that block a couple of times before. In general, I try to avoid blocks where there are lots of kids roaming around. On our block, everybody knows me and I know everybody. I know every brick and every tree trunk and every crack in the sidewalk. I know Mrs. Grimaldi, the lady who's always sitting by her window, and the old guy who walks up and down the street whistling like a bird. I know the deli on the corner where Mom gets our bagels, and the waitresses at the coffee shop who all call me "honey" and give me lollipops whenever they see me. I love my neighborhood of North River Heights, which is why it was so strange to be walking down these blocks feeling like it was all new to me suddenly.
paras.cn: 尽管比彻预备学校离我们家只有几个街区，但我以前只去过那个街区几次。总的来说，我尽量避开有很多孩子闲逛的街区。在我们自己的街区，每个人都认识我，我也认识每个人。我知道每一块砖、每一棵树干、人行道上的每一道裂缝。我认识格里马尔迪太太，那个总是坐在窗边的女士，还有那个在街上来回走、像鸟一样吹口哨的老爷爷。我认识街角妈妈给我们买百吉饼的熟食店，还有咖啡店里那些叫我“小甜心”、一见到我就给我棒棒糖的女服务员。我爱我的社区北河高地，这就是为什么走在这些街区上，突然感觉一切对我来说都那么陌生，会如此奇怪。

vocab.ex: In general, I prefer reading books to watching movies.
Groups of teenagers were roaming around the mall.
He carved his initials into the tree trunk.
I'll pick up some sandwiches from the deli for lunch.
The dentist gave the brave little girl a lollipop.

gram.name: 排比与首语重复法 (I know...)
gram.pattern: Repetition of a phrase at the beginning of successive clauses.
gram.function: 通过在连续的句子开头重复 'I know...'，作者建立了一种强烈的节奏感，并有力地强调了主角对其社区的熟悉和归属感。这种手法层层递进地列举了构成他“舒适区”的元素，与后面在新环境中的陌生感形成鲜明对比。

example.en: I have a dream... I have a dream... I have a dream today!
example.cn: 我有一个梦想......我有一个梦想......今天我有一个梦想！

gram.constraints: 是一种强有力的修辞手法，用于强调和增强情感。

paras.en: Amesfort Avenue, a street I've been down a million times, looked totally different for some reason. Full of people I never saw before, waiting for buses, pushing strollers. We crossed Amesfort and turned up Heights Place: Via walked next to me like she usually does, and Mom and Dad were behind us. As soon as we turned the corner, we saw all the kids in front of the school—hundreds of them talking to each other in little groups, laughing, or standing with their parents, who were talking with other parents. I kept my head way down.
paras.cn: 艾姆斯福特大道，一条我走过一百万次的街道，不知为何看起来完全不同了。满是我从未见过的人，等公交车的，推婴儿车的。我们穿过艾姆斯福特大道，拐上了高地广场：维娅像平常一样走在我旁边，爸爸妈妈跟在我们后面。我们一拐过街角，就看到了学校门前所有的孩子——几百个孩子，三三两两地互相交谈，笑着，或者和他们的父母站在一起，父母们则在和其他父母聊天。我一直把头埋得很低。

vocab.mean: 不知何故；不知什么原因
vocab.ex: For some reason, the key isn't working in the lock today.
She carefully pushed the stroller over the bumpy sidewalk.
We need to turn up the next street on the right.
The temperatures dropped way down below freezing.

gram.name: 简化的形容词短语/从句
gram.function: 通过省略主语和系动词来简化形容词从句，使其成为一个后置的修饰短语。'Full of people I never saw before, waiting for buses, pushing strollers' 描述了 'Amesfort Avenue' 的状态，它简化自 'The street was full of people...'。这种写法让句子更紧凑，节奏更快。

example.en: The man, tired from his long journey, fell asleep immediately.
example.cn: 那个人，因长途旅行而疲惫不堪，立刻就睡着了。

gram.constraints: 这是一种较为高级的书面语用法。

paras.en: "Everyone's just as nervous as you are," said Via in my ear. "Just remember that this is everyone's first day of school. Okay?" Mr. Tushman was greeting students and parents in front of the school entrance. I have to admit: so far, nothing bad had happened. I didn't catch anyone staring or even noticing me. Only once did I look up to see some girls looking my way and whispering with their hands cupped over their mouths, but they looked away when they saw me notice them.
paras.cn: “每个人都和你一样紧张，” 维娅在我耳边说。“只要记住这是每个人的开学第一天就行了。好吗？” 塔什曼先生正在学校入口前迎接学生和家长。我得承认：到目前为止，还没发生什么坏事。我没发现有谁盯着我看，甚至注意到我。只有一次我抬起头，看到几个女孩朝我这边看，用手捂着嘴窃窃私语，但她们看到我注意到她们时就把目光移开了。

vocab.ex: Before the big performance, the actor was as nervous as a kitten.
So far, I have completed three chapters of the book.

vocab.mean: 发现/撞见某人正在做某事
vocab.ex: The teacher caught the student cheating on the test.
He drank water from his cupped hands.

gram.name: look up to see (结果不定式)
gram.pattern: Action Verb + to + infinitive of result
gram.function: 用于描述一个动作所带来的意外或自然的结果。'I look up to see...' 意为“我抬头，结果看到...”，将抬头这个动作和看到的景象紧密连接起来，形成连贯的叙事流。

example.en: She opened the door to find a surprise party waiting for her.
example.cn: 她打开门，结果发现一个惊喜派对在等着她。

gram.constraints: 不定式描述的是主句动作之后发生的结果。

paras.en: We reached the front entrance. "Okay, so this is it, big boy," said Dad, putting his hands on top of my shoulders. "Have a great first day. I love you," said Via, giving me a big kiss and a hug. "You, too," I said. "I love you, Auggie," said Dad, hugging me. "Bye." Then Mom hugged me, but I could tell she was about to cry, which would have totally embarrassed me, so I just gave her a fast hard hug, turned, and disappeared into the school.
paras.cn: 我们到达了正门。“好了，就是这里了，大男孩，” 爸爸说，把手放在我的肩膀上。“第一天过得愉快。我爱你，” 维娅说，给了我一个大大的吻和拥抱。“你也是，” 我说。“我爱你，奥吉，” 爸爸拥抱我时说。“再见。” 然后妈妈拥抱了我，但我看得出她快要哭了，那会让我非常尴尬，所以我只是给了她一个快速而用力的拥抱，然后转身，消失在学校里。

vocab.mean: 就是这里了；关键时刻到了
vocab.ex: After months of training, this is it—the final race.
You're a big boy now, you can tie your own shoes.
His loud singing in the quiet library embarrassed his friends.
The rabbit disappeared into the bushes.

gram.name: 定语从句中的虚拟语气
gram.function: 这是一个非限定性定语从句，其中 'which' 指代前面整个主句 'she was about to cry'。从句内部使用了第三条件句的主句形式 'would have + 过去分词'，用来描述一个在过去本可能发生但被避免了的结果。

example.en: He missed the train, which would have made him late for the meeting.
example.cn: 他错过了火车，而那本来会让他开会迟到的。

gram.constraints: 用于描述一个未实现的过去的可能性后果。

paras.en: I went straight to room 301 on the third floor. Now I was glad I'd gone on that little tour, because I knew exactly where to go and didn't have to look up once. I noticed that some kids were definitely staring at me now. I did my thing of pretending not to notice. I went inside the classroom, and the teacher was writing on the chalkboard while all the kids started sitting at different desks. The desks were in a half circle facing the chalkboard, so I chose the desk in the middle toward the back, which I thought would make it harder for anyone to stare at me. I still kept my head way down, just looking up enough from under my bangs to see everyone's feet.
paras.cn: 我径直去了三楼的301室。现在我很高兴我参加了那次小小的参观，因为我确切地知道该去哪里，一次都不用抬头。我注意到现在有些孩子确实在盯着我看。我做了我的老一套，假装没注意到。我走进教室，老师正在黑板上写字，而所有的孩子都开始在不同的课桌前坐下。课桌呈半圆形面向黑板，所以我选了中间靠后的桌子，我想那样会更难让别人盯着我看。我仍然把头埋得很低，只从刘海下抬起一点，刚好能看到每个人的脚。

vocab.ex: When he got home, he went straight to his room.

vocab.mean: 做自己的事；按自己的方式行事（此处指习惯性动作）
vocab.ex: When he gets nervous, he does his thing of tapping his fingers on the table.
The students arranged their chairs in a half circle around the speaker.
She cut her bangs too short by accident.

gram.name: 非限定性定语从句
gram.function: 用于提供关于先行词的额外、非必要信息。'...I chose the desk in the middle toward the back, which I thought would make it harder...' 中的 'which' 指代前面整个选择座位的行为，解释了这个行为背后的原因。

example.en: He decided to leave early, which turned out to be a wise decision.
example.cn: 他决定早点离开，这后来被证明是一个明智的决定。

gram.constraints: 必须用逗号与主句隔开。

paras.en: As the desks started to fill up, I did notice that no one sat down next to me. A couple of times someone was about to sit next to me, then changed his or her mind at the last minute and sat somewhere else. "Hey, August." It was Charlotte, giving me her little wave as she sat down at a desk in the front of the class. Why anyone would ever choose to sit way up front in a class, I don't know.
paras.cn: 随着课桌渐渐被坐满，我确实注意到没有人坐在我旁边。有几次有人正要坐在我旁边，但在最后一刻改变了主意，坐到了别处。“嘿，奥古斯特。” 是夏洛特，她在一张教室前面的课桌坐下时，给了我她那小小的挥手。为什么会有人选择坐在教室最前面，我不知道。

vocab.ex: The theater started to fill up about ten minutes before the show.
I was going to have pizza, but I changed my mind and ordered pasta instead.
He cancelled the trip at the last minute.
We got to the concert early and found seats way up front.

gram.name: 强调助动词 (do/did)
gram.function: 在肯定句中使用助动词 'do/does/did' 来强调谓语动词，表示“确实；真的”。'I did notice that no one sat down next to me' 强调了“注意到”这个动作的真实性。

example.en: I know I forgot your birthday last year, but I did remember it this year!
example.cn: 我知道我去年忘了你的生日，但我今年确实记得！

gram.constraints: 助动词后必须跟动词原形。

paras.en: "Hey," I said, nodding hello. Then I noticed Julian was sitting a few seats away from her, talking to some other kids. I know he saw me, but he didn't say hello. Suddenly someone was sitting down next to me. It was Jack Will. Jack. "What's up," he said, nodding at me. "Hey, Jack," I answered, waving my hand, which I immediately wished I hadn't done because it felt kind of uncool.
paras.cn: “嘿，” 我说着，点头问好。然后我注意到朱利安坐在离她几个座位远的地方，正在和别的孩子说话。我知道他看到我了，但他没有打招呼。突然有人坐在了我旁边。是杰克·威尔。杰克。“嘿，你好，” 他说，对我点了点头。“嘿，杰克，” 我回答，挥了挥手，我立刻就后悔这么做了，因为它感觉有点傻。

vocab.ex: He was too far away to speak, so he just nodded hello.
She found her friend sitting a few seats away in the cinema.
"What's up?" he asked his friend as they met on the street.
Wearing socks with sandals is considered pretty uncool.

gram.name: wish + 过去完成时
gram.function: 用于表达对过去发生的事情的后悔或遗憾，希望它没有发生。'I immediately wished I hadn't done [that]' 表达了主角对自己刚刚挥手这一行为的立刻后悔。

example.en: I wish I had studied harder for the test.
example.cn: 我真希望我当时为考试更努力学习了。

gram.constraints: 用于对过去情况的虚拟。

paras.en: "Okay, kids, okay, everybody! Settle down," said the teacher, now facing us. She had written her name, Ms. Petosa, on the chalkboard. "Everybody find a seat, please. Come in," she said to a couple of kids who had just walked in the room. "There's a seat there, and right there." She hadn't noticed me yet. "Now, the first thing I want everyone to do is stop talking and . . ." She noticed me. ". . . put your backpacks down and quiet down." She had only hesitated for a millionth of a second, but I could tell the moment she saw me. Like I said: I'm used to it by now.
paras.cn: “好了，孩子们，好了，大家！安静下来，” 老师说，现在面向我们。她已经在黑板上写下了她的名字，佩托萨女士。“大家请找个座位。进来，” 她对刚走进房间的几个孩子说。“那里有个座位，还有那里。” 她还没注意到我。“现在，我要大家做的第一件事是停止说话，然后......” 她注意到我了。“......把你们的双肩包放下，安静下来。” 她只犹豫了百万分之一秒，但我能察觉到她看到我的那一刻。就像我说的：我现在已经习惯了。

vocab.ex: The teacher asked the noisy class to settle down.
The math equation was written on the chalkboard.
She didn't hesitate to help the person in need.
The chance of winning is less than a millionth of a percent.

gram.name: 省略号（用于戏剧性停顿）
gram.function: 用于表示说话被打断、停顿或思路的转换。'...stop talking and...' 和 '...put your backpacks down...' 之间的停顿，是由老师注意到主角这一事件引起的，省略号生动地再现了这个戏剧性的瞬间。

example.en: I wanted to say I love... but I couldn't find the words.
example.cn: 我想说我爱......但我找不到合适的词语。

gram.constraints: 是表现内心活动或外部干扰的有效标点。

paras.en: "I'm going to take attendance and do the seating chart," she continued, sitting on the edge of her desk. Next to her were three neat rows of accordion folders. "When I call your name, come up and I'll hand you a folder with your name on it. It contains your class schedule and your combination lock, which you should not try to open until I tell you to. Your locker number is written on the class schedule. Be forewarned that some lockers are not right outside this class but down the hall, and before anyone even thinks of asking: no, you cannot switch lockers and you can't switch locks. Then if there's time at the end of this period, we're all going to get to know each other a little better, okay? Okay."
paras.cn: “我要点名并安排座位表，” 她继续说，坐在她的书桌边上。她旁边是三排整齐的风琴夹。“当我叫到你的名字时，上前来，我会递给你一个写有你名字的文件夹。里面包含你的课程表和你的密码锁，在我告诉你们之前，不要尝试打开它。你的储物柜号码写在课程表上。预先警告一下，有些储物柜不在这间教室外面，而是在走廊尽头，而且在任何人想问之前我就告诉你们：不，你们不能换储物柜，也不能换锁。然后如果这段时间结束时还有时间，我们大家会更好地互相认识一下，好吗？好的。”

vocab.ex: The teacher always takes attendance at the start of class.
According to the new seating chart, I'm in the front row.
He organized his papers neatly in an accordion folder.
I forgot the numbers for my combination lock.
Forewarned is forearmed; knowing the risks helps you prepare.
Would you like to switch seats with me?

gram.name: 被动祈使句 (Be forewarned)
gram.function: 用于给出指令或警告，但听者是动作的接受者。'Be forewarned' 是一种正式且强硬的说法，意思是“你们要被预先警告”，强调了信息的严肃性。

example.en: Be prepared for a difficult exam.
example.cn: 要为一场困难的考试做好准备。

gram.constraints: 是一种较为正式的用法。

paras.en: She picked up the clipboard on her desk and started reading the names out loud. "Okay, so, Julian Albans?" she said, looking up. Julian raised his hand and said "Here" at the same time. "Hi, Julian," she said, making a note on her seating chart. She picked up the very first folder and held it out toward him. "Come pick it up," she said, kind of no-nonsense. He got up and took it from her. "Ximena Chin?"
paras.cn: 她拿起桌上的写字板，开始大声念名字。“好了，那么，朱利安·奥尔本斯？” 她抬起头说。朱利安举起手，同时说了声“到”。“嗨，朱利安，” 她说，在她的座位表上做了个记号。她拿起第一个文件夹，朝他递过去。“上来拿吧，” 她说，语气有点不容置疑。他站起来，从她手里接了过去。“西梅纳·陈？”

vocab.ex: The doctor made some notes on his clipboard.
He read the story out loud to the children.
He held out his hand to help her up.
She has a very no-nonsense approach to business.

gram.name: 祈使句
gram.function: 用于给出直接的指令或命令。'Come pick it up' 是一个清晰、直接的指令。

example.en: Close the door when you leave.
example.cn: 你离开时请关上门。

gram.constraints: 以动词原形开头。

paras.en: She handed a folder to each kid as she read off the names. As she went down the list, I noticed that the seat next to me was the only one still empty, even though there were two kids sitting at one desk just a few seats away. When she called the name of one of them, a big kid named Henry Joplin who already looked like a teenager, she said: "Henry, there's an empty desk right over there. Why don't you take that seat, okay?" She handed him his folder and pointed to the desk next to mine. Although I didn't look at him directly, I could tell Henry did not want to move next to me, just by the way he dragged his backpack on the floor as he came over, like he was moving in slow motion. Then he plopped his backpack up really high on the right side of the desk so it was kind of like a wall between his desk and mine.
paras.cn: 她一边念名字，一边递给每个孩子一个文件夹。当她顺着名单往下念时，我注意到我旁边的座位是唯一仍然空着的，尽管就在几个座位远的地方有​​两个孩子挤在一张桌子上。当她叫到其中一个人的名字，一个名叫亨利·乔普林、看起来已经像个青少年​​的大个子男孩时，她说：“亨利，那边正好有个空桌子。你为什么不坐那个座位呢，好吗？” 她递给他文件夹，并指向我旁边的桌子。虽然我没有直视他，但我能从他拖着背包走过来的样子看出亨利不想坐到我旁边，就像他在慢动作移动一样。然后他把背包“扑通”一声放到桌子的右侧，放得很高，以至于它有点像在他和我的桌子之间的一堵墙。

vocab.ex: The principal began to read off the names of the award winners.
He was too tired to lift his suitcase, so he had to drag it behind him.
The replay showed the winning goal in slow motion.
Exhausted, she plopped her heavy bags on the floor.

gram.name: I could tell by the way...
gram.pattern: I could tell + [conclusion] + by the way + [evidence]
gram.function: 表示“我能从…的方式中看出…”，用于解释自己做出某个判断所依据的行为线索。'...I could tell Henry did not want to move... just by the way he dragged his backpack...' 表明主角是通过观察亨利的行为来判断他真实意图的。

example.en: I could tell he was nervous by the way he kept fidgeting.
example.cn: 我能从他不停坐立不安的样子看出他很紧张。

gram.constraints: 'by the way' 后面跟一个描述方式的从句或短语。

paras.en: "Maya Markowitz?" Ms. Petosa was saying. "Here," said a girl about four desks down from me. "Miles Noury?" "Here," said the kid that had been sitting with Henry Joplin. As he walked back to his desk, I saw him shoot Henry a "poor you" look. "August Pullman?" said Ms. Petosa. "Here," I said quietly, raising my hand a bit.
paras.cn: “玛雅·马科维茨？” 佩托萨女士正在说。“到，” 离我约四张桌子远的一个女孩说。“迈尔斯·努里？” “到，” 那个一直和亨利·乔普林坐在一起的孩子说。当他走回自己的座位时，我看到他给了亨利一个“可怜的你”的眼神。“奥古斯特·普尔曼？” 佩托萨女士说。“到，” 我小声地说，稍微举了下手。

vocab.mean: （在一条线上）往下；离…有些距离
vocab.ex: His office is just a few doors down from mine.
She shot him a warning look when he started to tell the secret.
You have to work all weekend? Poor you!
If you know the answer, please raise your hand.

gram.name: 引语作形容词
gram.function: 将一个短语或句子放在引号内，用作形容词来修饰后面的名词，创造一个独特的、特定情境的描述。'a "poor you" look' 描述了一种眼神，其内容和情感就像是在说“可怜的你”。

example.en: He gave me an "I told you so" smile.
example.cn: 他给了我一个“我早就告诉过你”的微笑。

gram.constraints: 是一种非正式且富有表现力的用法。

paras.en: "Hi, August," she said, smiling at me very nicely when I went up to get my folder. I kind of felt everyone's eyes burning into my back for the few seconds I stood in the front of the class, and everybody looked down when I walked back to my desk. I resisted spinning the combination when I sat down, even though everyone else was doing it, because she had specifically told us not to. I was already pretty good at opening locks, anyway, because I've used them on my bike. Henry kept trying to open his lock but couldn't do it. He was getting frustrated and kind of cursing under his breath.
paras.cn: “嗨，奥古斯特，” 她说，当我去取文件夹时，非常友好地对我微笑。在我站在教室前面的那几秒钟里，我有点感觉所有人的目光都像火一样灼烧着我的后背，而当我走回座位时，所有人都低下了头。我坐下后忍住了没有去转动密码锁，尽管其他所有人都在这么做，因为她特地告诉我们不要。不管怎样，我本来就很擅长开锁，因为我在我的自行车上用过它们。亨利不停地尝试打开他的锁，但就是打不开。他变得很沮丧，还小声地咒骂着。

vocab.ex: The intense stare from the crowd felt like it was burning into his soul.
I couldn't resist eating another piece of cake.
The instructions specifically said not to open the box.
He was cursing under his breath after he missed the bus.

gram.name: feel + 宾语 + 现在分词
gram.function: 用于描述感觉到某个动作正在发生。'I felt everyone's eyes burning into my back' 是一种生动的感官描述，强调了被注视时的强烈不适感。

example.en: I felt a spider crawling up my leg.
example.cn: 我感觉到一只蜘蛛正在我的腿上爬。

gram.constraints: 是感官动词的常见用法之一。

paras.en: Ms. Petosa called out the next few names. The last name was Jack Will. After she handed Jack his folder, she said: "Okay, so, everybody write your combinations down somewhere safe that you won't forget, okay? But if you do forget, which happens at least three point two times per semester, Mrs. Garcia has a list of all the combination numbers. Now go ahead, take your locks out of your folders and spend a couple of minutes practicing how to open them, though I know some of you went ahead and did that anyway." She was looking at Henry when she said that. "And in the meanwhile, I'll tell you guys a little something about myself. And then you guys can tell me a little about yourselves and we'll, um, get to know each other. Sound good? Good."
paras.cn: 佩托萨女士叫了接下来的几个名字。最后一个是杰克·威尔。把文件夹递给杰克后，她说：“好了，那么，大家把你们的密码写在某个不会忘记的安全地方，好吗？但如果你们忘了，这种情况每学期至少发生三点二次，加西亚夫人那里有所有密码的列表。现在开始吧，把你们的锁从文件夹里拿出来，花几分钟练习一下怎么打开它们，虽然我知道你们有些人已经不管三七二十一先做了。” 她说这话时正看着亨利。“与此同时，我会告诉你们一些关于我自己的事。然后你们可以告诉我一些关于你们自己的事，我们呢，嗯，互相了解一下。听起来不错吧？好的。”

vocab.mean: （用于许可）开始吧；（用于叙事）不管三七二十一先做了
vocab.ex: If you're ready, you can go ahead and start the presentation.
This course is offered in the fall semester.
You need to practice every day to become good at playing the piano.
Dinner will be ready in an hour. In the meanwhile, you can set the table.
Let's go for a walk. Sound good?

gram.name: which 引导的插入语从句
gram.function: 用于在句子中间插入一个补充说明或评论，'which' 指代前面提到的“忘记密码”这件事。这种用法使语气更具对话感和幽默感。

example.en: My brother, who by the way is always late, is supposed to pick me up.
example.cn: 我哥哥，顺便说一句他总是迟到，应该来接我。

gram.constraints: 插入的从句前后都需要用逗号隔开。

paras.en: She smiled at everyone, though I felt like she was smiling at me the most. It wasn't a shiny smile, like Mrs. Garcia's smile, but a normal smile, like she meant it. She looked very different from what I thought teachers were going to look like. I guess I thought she'd look like Miss Fowl from Jimmy Neutron: an old lady with a big bun on top of her head. But, in fact, she looked exactly like Mon Mothma from Star Wars Episode IV: haircut kind of like a boy's, and a big white shirt kind of like a tunic.
paras.cn: 她对每个人微笑，尽管我感觉她对我笑得最多。那不是一个亮晶晶的微笑，不像加西亚夫人的那种，而是一个正常的微笑，像是真心的。她看起来和我所想象的老师的样子很不一样。我猜我以为她会长得像《天才小子吉米》里的福尔老师：一个头顶上梳着大发髻的老太太。但事实上，她看起来和《星球大战4》里的蒙·莫思马一模一样：发型有点像男孩，穿着一件有点像束腰外衣的大白衬衫。

vocab.ex: When I said I'm sorry, I really meant it.
The ballerina wore her hair in a tight bun.
He looks serious, but in fact, he has a great sense of humor.
In ancient Rome, many people wore a simple tunic.

gram.name: 使用 'but, in fact' 进行对比
gram.function: 用于强烈地对比预期与现实之间的差异。首先陈述一个想法或假设（'I thought she'd look like...'），然后用 'But, in fact' 引出现实情况，强调其出乎意料。

example.en: I thought the exam would be easy. But, in fact, it was incredibly difficult.
example.cn: 我原以为考试会很简单。但事实上，它难得令人难以置信。

gram.constraints: 是一种清晰的对比和澄清结构。

paras.en: She turned around and started writing on the chalkboard. Henry still couldn't get his lock to open, and he was getting more and more frustrated every time someone else popped one open. He got really annoyed when I was able to open mine on the first try. The funny thing is, if he hadn't put the backpack between us, I most definitely would have offered to help him.
paras.cn: 她转过身，开始在黑板上写字。亨利仍然打不开他的锁，而且每当别人“啪”地打开一个时，他就变得越来越沮丧。当我第一次尝试就打开我的锁时，他变得非常恼火。有趣的是，如果他没有把背包放在我们之间，我绝对会主动提出帮助他。

vocab.ex: He felt frustrated when he couldn't solve the puzzle.
The lid on the jar finally popped open with a loud noise.
She solved the difficult puzzle on the first try.
If you ask him, he will most definitely say yes.

gram.name: 第三条件句
gram.pattern: If + past perfect, ... would have + past participle
gram.function: 用于描述与过去事实相反的假设情况及其可能的结果。'if he hadn't put the backpack between us, I... would have offered to help' 描述了一个未发生的过去情况（他确实放了背包）以及因此未能实现的过去的可能性。

example.en: If it hadn't rained, we would have gone to the beach.
example.cn: 如果当时没下雨，我们就去海滩了。

gram.constraints: 用于对过去情况的虚拟假设。

paras.en: Ms. Petosa told us a little about who she was. It was boring stuff about where she originally came from, and how she always wanted to teach, and she left her job on Wall Street about six years ago to pursue her "dream" and teach kids. She ended by asking if anyone had any questions, and Julian raised his hand. "Yes . . ." She had to look at the list to remember his name. "Julian." "That's cool about how you're pursuing your dream," he said. "Thank you!" "You're welcome!" He smiled proudly.
paras.cn: 佩托萨女士简单地告诉了我们她是谁。都是些无聊的东西，关于她最初来自哪里，她如何一直想教书，以及大约六年前她辞去了华尔街的工作来追求她的“梦想”并教孩子们。她最后问是否有人有任何问题，朱利安举起了手。“是的……” 她不得不看名单才想起他的名字。“朱利安。” “您追求梦想的方式很酷，” 他说。“谢谢你！” “不客气！” 他骄傲地笑了。

vocab.ex: This building was originally a library before it became a museum.

vocab.mean: 华尔街（美国金融中心的代名词）
vocab.ex: He worked in finance on Wall Street for twenty years.
She moved to Hollywood to pursue her dream of becoming an actress.
After winning the race, he proudly held up his trophy.

gram.name: 引号（表示怀疑或引用）
gram.function: 除了引用对话，引号也可以用来表示对某个词语的特殊强调、怀疑或讽刺。叙述者将 'dream' 放在引号里，暗示他并不完全相信或觉得这个词有点陈词滥调。

example.en: He told me about his "brilliant" idea, but I wasn't impressed.
example.cn: 他告诉了我他那个“绝妙的”主意，但我并没觉得怎么样。

gram.constraints: 这是一种 subtle 的修辞手法，传达了叙述者的态度。

paras.en: "Okay, so why don't you tell us a little about yourself, Julian? Actually, here's what I want everyone to do. Think of two things you want other people to know about you. Actually, wait a minute: how many of you came from the Beecher lower school?" About half the kids raised their hands. "Okay, so a few of you already know each other. But the rest of you, I guess, are new to the school, right? Okay, so everyone think of two things you want other people to know about you—and if you know some of the other kids, try to think of things they don't already know about you. Okay? Okay. So let's start with Julian and we'll go around the room."
paras.cn: “好的，那么你为什么不告诉我们一些关于你自己的事呢，朱利安？其实，这是我希望大家做的。想两件你希望别人知道的关于你的事情。哦，等等：你们中有多少人是从比彻小学部来的？” 大约一半的孩子举起了手。“好的，那么你们中有些人已经互相认识了。但我猜，其余的人是新来的，对吧？好的，那么每个人都想两件你希望别人知道的关于你的事情——而且如果你认识其他一些孩子，试着想一些他们还不知道的关于你的事。好吗？好的。那么我们从朱利安开始，然后我们绕着教室一圈来。”

vocab.ex: Can you tell me a little about your hometown?
If you know the answer, please raise your hand.
I ate two cookies and saved the rest of them for later.
The teacher decided to go around the room and have each student introduce themselves.

gram.name: 话语标记（课堂管理）
gram.function: 用于组织语言、转换思路和管理对话流程。老师通过使用这些短语，生动地展示了她如何即时调整自己的计划，从针对一个人提问转向一个全班参与的活动，这让她的指令听起来更自然、更像真实的思考过程。

example.en: Okay, so let's start with chapter one. Actually, wait a minute, let's review last week's homework first.
example.cn: 好的，那么我们从第一章开始。哦，等等，我们还是先复习一下上周的作业吧。

gram.constraints: 是口语中非常常见的表达方式。

paras.en: Julian scrunched up his face and started tapping his forehead like he was thinking really hard. "Okay, whenever you're ready," Ms. Petosa said. "Okay, so number one is that—" "Do me a favor and start with your names, okay?" Ms. Petosa interrupted. "Oh, okay. So my name is Julian. And the number one thing I'd like to tell everyone about myself is that . . . I just got Battleground Mystic for my Wii and it's totally awesome. And the number two thing is that we got a Ping-Pong table this summer."
paras.cn: 朱利安皱起脸，开始敲他的额头，好像在非常努力地思考。“好了，你随时准备好都可以开始，” 佩托萨女士说。“好的，那么第一件是——” “帮个忙，从你的名字开始，好吗？” 佩托萨女士打断道。“哦，好的。我的名字是朱利安。我想告诉大家的关于我自己的第一件事是……我刚为我的Wii买到了《战场秘境》，它超赞的。第二件事是我们今年夏天买了一张乒乓球桌。”

vocab.ex: The baby scrunched up his face when he tasted the lemon.
She was tapping her fingers on the desk impatiently.
He wiped the sweat from his forehead with the back of his hand.

vocab.mean: 帮个忙（也可用于委婉地提出要求）
vocab.ex: Could you do me a favor and close the window?
We had an awesome time at the concert.

gram.name: 使用'number one... number two'列举
gram.pattern: Number one is... And number two is...
gram.function: 一种非常清晰和口语化的列举方式，用于按顺序介绍要点。Julian用这种结构来介绍他想分享的两件事。

example.en: My top two favorite foods are pizza and ice cream. Number one is pizza, and number two is ice cream.
example.cn: 我最喜欢的两种食物是披萨和冰淇淋。第一是披萨，第二是冰淇淋。

gram.constraints: 通常用于非正式的口头陈述中。

paras.en: "Very nice, I love Ping-Pong," said Ms. Petosa. "Does anyone have any questions for Julian?" "Is Battleground Mystic multiplayer or one player?" said the kid named Miles. "Not those kinds of questions, guys," said Ms. Petosa. "Okay, so how about you. . . ." She pointed to Charlotte, probably because her desk was closest to the front. "Oh, sure." Charlotte didn't hesitate for even a second, like she knew exactly what she wanted to say. "My name is Charlotte. I have two sisters, and we just got a new puppy named Suki in July. We got her from an animal shelter and she's so, so cute!" "That's great, Charlotte, thank you," said Ms. Petosa. "Okay, then, who's next?"
paras.cn: “非常好，我喜欢乒乓球，” 佩托萨女士说。“有人对朱利安有什么问题吗？” “《战场秘境》是多人游戏还是一人玩的？” 名叫迈尔斯的孩子说。“不是那种问题，伙计们，” 佩托萨女士说。“好吧，那么你呢......” 她指向夏洛特，可能是因为她的座位离前面最近。“哦，当然。” 夏洛特一秒钟也没犹豫，好像她确切地知道自己想说什么。“我的名字是夏洛特。我有两个姐姐，我们七月份刚养了一只叫苏琪的新小狗。我们是从动物收容所领养的她，她超级、超级可爱！” “太棒了，夏洛特，谢谢你，” 佩托萨女士说。“好的，那么，下一个是谁？”

vocab.ex: The new video game has a fantastic multiplayer mode.
She didn't hesitate to help the person in need.
They decided to adopt a small puppy from the shelter.
Volunteering at the local animal shelter is a rewarding experience.
Look at that little kitten playing with the yarn; it's so cute!

gram.name: 同位语（用于指名）
gram.function: 用于对前面的名词进行补充说明，提供其具体名称。'...a new puppy named Suki...' 中的 'named Suki' 就是 'a new puppy' 的同位语。

example.en: I have a cat named Whiskers.
example.cn: 我有一只名叫威斯克斯的猫。

gram.constraints: 是一种常见的介绍名称的方式。

paras.en: "Like a lamb to the slaughter": Something that you say about someone who goes somewhere calmly, not knowing that something unpleasant is going to happen to them. I Googled it last night. That's what I was thinking when Ms. Petosa called my name and suddenly it was my turn to talk.
paras.cn: “如同待宰的羔羊”：用来形容某人平静地去某个地方，却不知道将有不愉快的事情发生在他们身上。我昨晚谷歌了一下。当佩托萨女士叫到我的名字，突然轮到我说话时，我心里想的就是这个。

vocab.mean: 待宰的羔羊（比喻天真无知地走向危险）
vocab.ex: The inexperienced team walked onto the field like lambs to the slaughter against the champions.
Despite the chaos around him, he spoke calmly and clearly.
There was an unpleasant smell coming from the kitchen.
If you don't know the answer, just Google it.

gram.name: 定义习语
gram.function: 通过直接给出习语的定义来作为章节的引言，为整个章节设定了基调和主题。这种文学手法让读者立刻明白主角内心的感受和预感。

example.en: To bite the bullet: to force yourself to do something unpleasant or difficult.
example.cn: 咬紧牙关：强迫自己去做不愉快或困难的事情。

gram.constraints: 是一种有效的设定主题的方式。

paras.en: "My name is August," I said, and yeah, I kind of mumbled it. "What?" said someone. "Can you speak up, honey?" said Ms. Petosa. "My name is August," I said louder, forcing myself to look up. "I, um . . . have a sister named Via and a dog named Daisy. And, um . . . that's it." "Wonderful," said Ms. Petosa. "Anyone have questions for August?" No one said anything.
paras.cn: “我的名字是奥古斯特，” 我说，而且，是的，我有点含糊地说了出来。“什么？” 有人说。“你能大点声吗，宝贝？” 佩托萨女士说。“我的名字是奥古斯特，” 我大声说，强迫自己抬起头。“我，嗯……有个姐姐叫维娅和一只狗叫黛西。而且，嗯……就这些了。” “好极了，” 佩托萨女士说。“有人对奥古斯特有什么问题吗？” 谁也没说话。
